prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user wants to know if the person who bought the yoga pass is in the wrong. The situation is their wife is pregnant and has hypermesis, which is severe morning sickness. The husband got her a prenatal yoga pass for her birthday. She didn't appreciate it, thought it was rude, and her friends agreed with her.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband's intention was good—he wanted her to exercise, get fresh air, and maybe improve her mood. He researched prenatal yoga, so he thought it was a safe option. But his wife is very sick, on temporary disability, and can't even go out except for medical visits. She might feel that the gift is dismissive of her current condition. Even though yoga is prenatal, she's too ill right now. She might feel like he's not taking her condition seriously, thinking she should be doing things she can't. The friends backing her up suggests that the gesture might not have been considered thoughtful given her current state. The husband might have overlooked her current physical and emotional state. So, even if the intention was good, the timing and appropriateness might be issues. The wife's reaction isn't just about the gift but possibly about feeling misunderstood or not supported. The husband might be in the wrong because he didn't consider her feelings about being told to do something she's too sick to do. Alternatively, he's trying to help but maybe misjudged the situation. But the consensus from her friends and her reaction indicates that the gift was tone-deaf. So the answer might be A, the husband is in the wrong because the gift, while well-intentioned, wasn't appropriate given her current health state and could be seen as insensitive.
